greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: The number of unordered partitions {a,b} of n such that a and b are composite.
comment: Last occurrence of n is a(A014092(n+4)). - _Anthony Browne_, May 25 2016
link: J. Stauduhar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: For n=8, in the set {{7,1},{6,2},{5,3},{4,4}}, {4,4} is the only partition {a,b} where a and b are both composite, so a(8)=1.
For n=12, we have partitions {8,4} and {6,6}, so a(12)=2.
mathematica: nn = 76; Rest[Transpose[CoefficientList[Series[Product[1/(1 - y x^i), {i, Select[Range[2, nn], ! PrimeQ[#] &]}], {x,0,nn}], {x, y}]][[3]]] (* _Geoffrey Critzer_, Jan 31 2015 *)
f[n_] := Count[ PrimeQ@ Rest@ IntegerPartitions[ n, {2}], {False, False}]; Array[f, 76] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Feb 04 2015 *)
results.author: _J. Stauduhar_, Apr 16 2013
